title: RStudio::conf 2022
text: This workshop provides an introduction to machine learning with R using the tidymodels framework, a collection of packages for modeling and machine learning using tidyverse principles. We will build, evaluate, compare, and tune predictive models. Along the way, weâ€™ll learn about key concepts in machine learning including overfitting, resampling, and feature engineering. Learners will gain knowledge about good predictive modeling practices, as well as hands-on experience using tidymodels packages like parsnip, rsample, recipes, yardstick, tune, and workflows.

title: RStudio::conf 2022
text:
Where/When
Washington DC, July 25-26th (9:00 A.M. â€“ 5:00 P.M)

title: RStudio::conf 2022
text:
Should I take this course?
This course assumes intermediate R knowledge. If you can use the magrittr pipe and tidyverse functions from packages like readr, dplyr, tidyr, and ggplot2 to read data into R, transform and reshape data, and make a wide variety of graphs, this tutorial is for you. We expect participants to have some exposure to basic statistical concepts, but NOT intermediate or expert familiarity with modeling or machine learning.

title: RStudio::conf 2022
text:
Instructors
Max Kuhn, Davis Vaughan, Julia Silge, Hannah Frick, Emil Hvitfeldt, Simon Couch, and David Robinson

title: RStudio::conf 2022
text:
Content

Part 1 - Introduction: A review of R and tidyverse fundamentals and a high-level view of the modeling process.
Part 2 - Data Splitting and Basic Modeling: The how and why of partitioning your data. An overview of Base R modeling syntax. An introduction to the parsnip package for creating models.
Part 3 - Evaluating Models: Once you have a model, how to you properly tell if it is any good? Introduces resampling tools for model evaluation.

title: Machine learning with tidymodels
text: These are the materials for workshops on tidymodels. The tidymodels framework is a collection of packages for modeling and machine learning using tidyverse principles. This workshop provides an introduction to machine learning with R using the tidymodels framework, a collection of packages for modeling and machine learning using tidyverse principles. We will build, evaluate, compare, and tune predictive models. Along the way, weâ€™ll learn about key concepts in machine learning including overfitting, resampling, and feature engineering. Learners will gain knowledge about good predictive modeling practices, as well as hands-on experience using tidymodels packages like parsnip, rsample, recipes, yardstick, tune, and workflows.

title: Machine learning with tidymodels
text:
Is this workshop for me?
This course assumes intermediate R knowledge. This workshop is for you if:

You can use the magrittr pipe %>% and/or native pipe |>
You are familiar with functions from dplyr, tidyr, and ggplot2
You can read data into R, transform and reshape data, and make a wide variety of graphs

We expect participants to have some exposure to basic statistical concepts, but NOT intermediate or expert familiarity with modeling or machine learning.

title: Machine learning with tidymodels
text:
Preparation
Please join the workshop with a computer that has the following installed (all available for free):

A recent version of R, available at https://cran.r-project.org/
A recent version of RStudio Desktop (RStudio Desktop Open Source License), available at https://www.rstudio.com/download
The following R packages, which you can install by connecting to the internet, opening RStudio, and running in the R console:


install.packages(c("tidyverse", "tidymodels", "rpart", 
                   "ranger", "vetiver", "rpart.plot"))

title: 1 - Introduction
text:
Workshop policies

Identify the exits closest to you in case of emergency
Please review the rstudio::conf code of conduct, which applies to all workshops
CoC issues can be addressed three ways:

In person: contact any rstudio::conf staff member or the conference registration desk
By email: send a message to conf@rstudio.com
By phone: call 844-448-1212

Please do not photograph people wearing red lanyards
A chill-out room is available for neurologically diverse attendees on TKTK

library(tidymodels)

â”€â”€ Attaching packages â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ tidymodels 0.2.0 â”€â”€

title: 3 - Evaluating models
text:
Metrics for model performance 




augment(tree_fit, new_data = frog_test) %>%
  metrics(latency, .pred)

# A tibble: 3 Ã— 3
  .metric .estimator .estimate
  <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
1 rmse    standard      59.2  
2 rsq     standard       0.380
3 mae     standard      40.2  




RMSE: difference between the predicted and observed values â¬‡ï¸
\(R^2\): squared correlation between the predicted and observed values â¬†ï¸
MAE: similar to RMSE, but mean absolute error â¬‡ï¸

title: 3 - Evaluating models
text:
Metrics for model performance 

augment(tree_fit, new_data = frog_test) %>%
  rmse(latency, .pred)

# A tibble: 1 Ã— 3
  .metric .estimator .estimate
  <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
1 rmse    standard        59.2

title: 3 - Evaluating models
text:
Metrics for model performance 

augment(tree_fit, new_data = frog_test) %>%
  group_by(reflex) %>%
  rmse(latency, .pred)

# A tibble: 3 Ã— 4
  reflex .metric .estimator .estimate
  <fct>  <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
1 low    rmse    standard        94.3
2 mid    rmse    standard       101. 
3 full   rmse    standard        51.2

title: 3 - Evaluating models
text:
Metrics for model performance 

frog_metrics <- metric_set(rmse, msd)
augment(tree_fit, new_data = frog_test) %>%
  frog_metrics(latency, .pred)

# A tibble: 2 Ã— 3
  .metric .estimator .estimate
  <chr>   <chr>          <dbl>
1 rmse    standard      59.2  
2 msd     standard      -0.908

title: 3 - Evaluating models
text:
Create a random forest model 

rf_spec <- rand_forest(trees = 1000, mode = "regression")
rf_spec

Random Forest Model Specification (regression)

Main Arguments:
  trees = 1000

Computational engine: ranger

title: 3 - Evaluating models
text:
Create a random forest model 

rf_wf <- workflow(latency ~ ., rf_spec)
rf_wf

What if we want to compare more models?

And we want to understand if these are important differences?

title: 3 - Evaluating models

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Data on tree frog hatching

library(tidyverse)

data("tree_frogs", package = "stacks")
tree_frogs <- tree_frogs %>%
  filter(!is.na(latency)) %>%
  select(-c(clutch, hatched))


Red-eyed tree frog embryos can hatch earlier than their normal ~7 days if they detect potential predator threat!
Type ?stacks::tree_frogs to learn more about this dataset, including references.

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Data on tree frog hatching

glimpse(tree_frogs)

Rows: 572
Columns: 5
$ treatment <chr> "control", "control", "control", "control", "control", "gentâ€¦
$ reflex    <fct> full, low, full, mid, full, full, full, full, full, full, fuâ€¦
$ age       <dbl> 466965, 361180, 401595, 357810, 397440, 463230, 393900, 4690â€¦
$ t_o_d     <chr> "morning", "night", "afternoon", "night", "afternoon", "mornâ€¦
$ latency   <dbl> 22, 360, 106, 180, 60, 39, 214, 50, 224, 63, 33, 94, 19, 25,â€¦

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Data on tree frog hatching

N = 572
a numeric outcome latency
4 other variables

treatment, reflex, and t_o_d are nominal predictors
age is a numeric predictor

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Data splitting and spending
For machine learning, we typically split data into training and test sets:


The training set is used to estimate model parameters.
The test set is used to find an independent assessment of model performance.



Do not ğŸš« use the test set during training.

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
The more data we spend ğŸ¤‘


the better estimates weâ€™ll get.

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Data splitting and spending

Spending too much data in training prevents us from a good assessment of predictive performance.
Spending too much in testing keeps us from finding a good estimate of model parameters.

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Your turn

When is a good time to split your data?



03:00

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Data splitting and spending 

library(tidymodels)

set.seed(123)
frog_split <- initial_split(tree_frogs, strata = latency)
frog_split

<Analysis/Assess/Total>
<428/144/572>

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Data splitting and spending 

frog_train <- training(frog_split)
frog_test <- testing(frog_split)

$ t_o_d     <chr> "morning", "morning", "morning", "morning", "morning", "afteâ€¦

Rows: 144
Columns: 5
$ treatment <chr> "control", "control", "control", "control", "gentamicin", "câ€¦
$ reflex    <fct> full, low, full, mid, full, full, full, full, full, full, fuâ€¦
$ age       <dbl> 466965, 361180, 401595, 357810, 463230, 469065, 466160, 4658â€¦
$ t_o_d     <chr> "morning", "night", "afternoon", "night", "morning", "morninâ€¦

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Your turn

Split your data so 20% is held out for the test set.



05:00

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
Data splitting and spending 

set.seed(123)
frog_split <- initial_split(tree_frogs, prop = 0.8, strata = latency)
frog_train <- training(frog_split)
frog_test <- testing(frog_split)

nrow(frog_train)

[1] 456

nrow(frog_test)

[1] 116

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
ggplot(frog_train, aes(latency)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20)



Remember how we used strata = latency?

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
quartiles <- quantile(frog_train$latency, probs = c(1:3)/4)
ggplot(frog_train, aes(latency)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = quartiles, color = train_color, 
             size = 1.5, lty = 2)



Stratification often helps, with very little downside

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
ggplot(frog_train, aes(latency, treatment, fill = treatment)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.5, show.legend = FALSE)

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
frog_train %>%
  ggplot(aes(latency, reflex, fill = reflex)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.3, show.legend = FALSE)

title: 2 - Your data budget
text:
ggplot(frog_train, aes(reflex, age)) +
  stat_summary_2d(aes(z = latency), 
                  alpha = 0.7, binwidth = c(1, 5e3)) +
  scale_fill_viridis_c() +
  labs(fill = "mean latency")

title: 2 - What makes a model?
text:
Your turn

How do you fit a linear model in R?
How many different ways can you think of?



03:00





lm for generalized linear model
glmnet for regularized regression
keras for regression using TensorFlow
stan for Bayesian regression
spark for large data sets

title: 2 - What makes a model?
text:
Why a workflow()? 


Workflows are smarter with new data than model.matrix() in terms of new factor levels




You can use other preprocessors (more on feature engineering tomorrow!)




A workflow captures the entire modeling process




fit() and predict() apply to all the estimation steps




They can help organize your work when working with multiple models

title: 2 - What makes a model?
text:
A model workflow  

tree_spec <-
  decision_tree() %>% 
  set_mode("regression")

workflow() %>%
  add_model(tree_spec) %>%
  add_formula(latency ~ .) %>%
  fit(data = frog_train) 

â•â• Workflow [trained] â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

Model: decision_tree()

 1) root 456 2197966.00  92.90351

     5) treatment=gentamicin 125  119197.90  73.96800 *

      13) reflex=low 11  158918.20 196.72730 *

title: 2 - What makes a model?
text:
A model workflow  

tree_spec <-
  decision_tree() %>% 
  set_mode("regression")

workflow() %>%
  add_model(tree_spec) %>%
  add_variables(outcomes = latency, predictors = everything()) %>%
  fit(data = frog_train) 

â•â• Workflow [trained] â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

title: 2 - What makes a model?
text:
Your turn

Run the tree_wf chunk in your .Rmd.
Edit this code so it:

creates a different model
uses one of the other workflow() interfaces




05:00

title: 2 - What makes a model?
text:
Predict with your model  
How do you use your new model tree_fit?

tree_spec <-
  decision_tree() %>% 
  set_mode("regression")

tree_fit <-
  workflow(latency ~ ., tree_spec) %>% 
  fit(data = frog_train)

title: 2 - What makes a model?
text:
Your turn

Run:
predict(tree_fit, new_data = frog_test)
What do you get?



03:00

title: 2 - What makes a model?
text:
Your turn

Run:
augment(tree_fit, new_data = frog_test)
What do you get?



03:00

title: 2 - What makes a model?
text:
Understand your model  
How do you understand your new model tree_fit?

You can use your fitted workflow for model and/or prediction explanations:



overall variable importance, such as with the vip package




flexible model explainers, such as with the DALEXtra package



Learn more at https://www.tmwr.org/explain.html

title: 2 - What makes a model?
text:
Understand your model  
How do you understand your new model tree_fit?

title: 2 - What makes a model?
text:
Understand your model  
How do you understand your new model tree_fit?

library(rpart.plot)
tree_fit %>%
  extract_fit_engine() %>%
  rpart.plot()

You can extract_*() several components of your fitted workflow.

title: 2 - What makes a model?
text:
Your turn

Read the documentation for object extraction.
Try out some extraction methods on your trained workflow.



05:00

title: 2 - What makes a model?
text:
Deploy your model   
How do you use your new model tree_fit in production?

library(vetiver)
v <- vetiver_model(tree_fit, "frog_hatching")
v


â”€â”€ frog_hatching â”€ <butchered_workflow> model for deployment 
A rpart regression modeling workflow using 4 features


Learn more at https://vetiver.rstudio.com/

title: 2 - What makes a model?
text:
Predict with your model   
How do you use your new model tree_fit in production?

library(plumber)
pr() %>%
  vetiver_api(v)

# Plumber router with 2 endpoints, 4 filters, and 1 sub-router.
# Use `pr_run()` on this object to start the API.
